Plus, doctors are very strict about giving out prescriptions for these drugs, saving them only for the very sick and vulnerable population. This is interesting science, but I don't think it would be something available to the general population.

I thought that the Common cold would be the LAST virus cured. The reasons would be side effects and cost.

We'd first create anti-virals that worked, but they were really expensive and would keep you on your back for a month. Not a problem dealing with AIDS, but you wouldn't use them for a cold. As the costs went down and the meds got better, they'd be prescribed for less and less serious illnesses. The common cold being at the bottom of the list because of it's short duration and low danger.

I always hear about all these miracle treatments that work in mice but either don't in humans or are not there yet. If an alien race were researching us, I wonder if they would conclude that humans have a bizarre obsession with keeping their mice healthy.

While cutting a viral infection short sounds nice, there is a huge downside to antiviral drugs.

As explained in the video, when a virus dies, it releases a toxin, and some of them are quite nasty. A few years ago, I was prescribed an antiviral drug, called acyclovir for adult Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease. Even though I took charcoal with each dose and drank lots of fluids advised by my doctor, I was stuck in bed with a nauseating migraine for the first three days. While that was absolutely miserable, the sores in my mouth started to heal by day four, and I was able to eat normally by day seven.

Was it worth it? Absolutely. Without the acyclovir, I could have been sick for as long as ten days, and some of the viruses that cause HFMD can also cause viral meningitis.

As for the common cold, even though I have often contracted secondary sinus infections from it, I would rather deal with the common cold and a sinus infection. Although they're miserable, the common cold and sinus infections very rarely have serious complications, so, I don't believe the benefits of an antiviral drug for the common cold would be worth the side effects, with the exception of those who are immunocompromised.

As with any treatment, we must consider, is it really worth it?

I don't know if we SHOULD cure the common cold? It's almost never fatal, rarely more than a nuisance, and gives our immune systems something to keep them on their toes. And while new anti-virals are undoubtedly something we need, we should be careful that the same thing doesn't happen that is happening now with antibiotics. We certainly don't want to end up breeding super-viral infections.

In 1986 we were the first to sequence a Human rhinovirus and to determine the gene boundaries (Picornaviridae have a very peculiar system there) via protein sequencing (none of this was trivial back then). This was 32 years ago. Some of my then colleagues already retired, having spent their scientific lives without ever getting really close to the goal we had in mind back then.

But should we cure the common cold? Let's clarify, if we find old viral dna in our dna then the evolution of our species could be tied to getting certain viruses or infections also if we cure viruses that don't kill or cause severe deformity then we remove the training wheels from our bodies. Viruses from other species could then evolve to be more deadly or just plain become more deadly because the body wouldn't know what to do. If we cured all viruses on the planet then what about space viruses?  A bit far fetched now the possibility still exist.
